I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2006  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical 
assistance (TA) to support government efforts to strengthen the regulatory framework for urban 
wastewater management (UWM) and solid waste management (SWM), focusing on small cities 
and towns. Fact-finding for the TA was undertaken in October 2007, and an understanding was 
reached with the Government on the impact and outcome, methodology and key activities, cost 
estimates,  financing  plan,  and  implementation  arrangements  for  the  TA.1  The  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Since the PRC initiated economic reforms in 1978, continuous economic growth has 
been accompanied by rapid urbanization. The urban population2 has grown from 160 million in 
1975 to about 577.1 million in 2006. The urbanization rate increased from 17% to 43.9% in the 
same  period,  and  is  expected  to  reach  55%  (or  about  700  million)  in  2030.  This  rapid 
urbanization  over  the  past  three  decades  of  economic  reform  was  largely  fueled  by  the 
transformation of suburban areas from farming to non-farming activities, and by the massive 
migration of surplus rural labor to urban areas. The number of cities in the PRC increased from 
193 in 1978 to 661 in 2006. There are also 19,522 towns. Of the total urban population of 
577.1 million in 2006, an estimated 115.5 million live in small cities and 239.1 million in towns. 
The combined population of small cities and towns is 354.6 million or 61.4% of the total urban 
population.3 The Government highlighted sustainable urbanization as a key policy priority in the 
11th Five-Year Plan (FYP) (2006–2010). 
 
3.  The enormous volume of wastewater and solid waste generated by the PRC’s urban 
areas  poses  a  major environmental  threat to  the  country’s  rivers,  lakes,  and underground 
aquifers. In 2006, the PRC generated about 296.6 billion cubic meters of wastewater4—about 
55.3% from municipal sources and 44.7% from industrial sources. Currently, about 90% of 
industrial wastewater is treated before discharge to a municipal sewer. Municipal wastewater is 
a major contributor to pollution of the PRC’s rivers and lakes. As of 2006, only about 57% (34% 
in 2000) of urban wastewater was treated; the rest was discharged untreated into rivers and 
lakes. The State Environment Protection Administration maintains a network of 3,200 water 
quality monitoring stations. According to the 2004 State of the Environment Report, about 41% 
of the water in the seven major river basins5 does not meet the class III national water quality 
standard.6 Of the 50 lakes that are regularly monitored, 13 are partially polluted, 19 are seriously 
polluted, and only 18 meet the class III standard. Surface water sources serving municipal water 
supply systems are polluted to levels unacceptable under the current water quality standards.  
 
4.  The amount of solid waste generated by urban areas has also expanded rapidly. In 
2006, the PRC generated 186 million tons of solid waste—representing an increase of 57% over

the 2001 volume of 118 million tons. However, the increase in treatment capacity has not kept 
pace  with  the  increased  solid  waste  volume,  and  the  treatment  capacity  that  has  been 
developed is mainly for large cities. Few small cities and towns have wastewater, solid waste, 
and hazardous waste disposal facilities. In addition to direct adverse impacts on public health, 
the growing and uncontrolled disposal of solid waste contributes to increasing contamination of 
groundwater supplies through inadequate leachate collection systems. There is an urgent need 
to prepare and promulgate a national policy framework and guidelines for UWM and SWM for 
small cities and towns in the PRC.  
 
5.  To  arrest  the  trend  of  environmental  pollution  and  improve  the  quality  of  the 
environment, the Government adopted the long-term goal of building a resource-efficient and 
environment-friendly society, with the specific target of reducing major pollutants (including 
chemical oxygen demand) per unit of gross domestic product by 10% during the 11th FYP. 
Cities are required to raise the rate of wastewater treatment to at least 70% by the end of the 
11th FYP. Between 1998 and 2005, the Government invested a total of CNY279 billion in 
wastewater  treatment  infrastructure,  involving  some  2,000  wastewater  treatment  plants.  A 
recent  government  audit  of  these  wastewater  treatment  plants  indicated  that  one  major 
constraint was the lack of funds for operation and maintenance (O&M) because of inadequate 
tariff levels. An additional CNY300 billion of government funding has been earmarked for UWM 
treatment and reuse, and SWM projects for the 11th FYP. There is, therefore, an urgent need to 
improve the effectiveness and sustainability of existing and future UWM and SWM facilities, 
through tariff reforms, innovative financing mechanisms, and management regimes. 
 
6.  The Government has recognized the importance of tariff reforms to raise funds for both 
construction and O&M of UWM treatment and SWM, and demonstrated a strong commitment 
toward market-based reforms for UWM and SWM. The state council decision on implementing a 
scientific  approach  to  development  and  strengthening  environmental  protection,  issued  in 
December 2005, requires the implementation of tariffs for UWM and solid waste on the basis of 
full cost recovery, and allowance of a small margin of profit. It also allows for provision of 
subsidies by local governments for O&M of waste management facilities, when the revenues 
cannot cover the full costs.  
 
7.  The Ministry of Construction (MOC) is responsible for developing national policies and 
guidelines  for  the  management  of  UWM  and  solid  waste,  including  waste  collection, 
transportation, treatment, disposal, and tariff setting. MOC is also responsible for overseeing 
development plans and investments in UWM and SWM. Municipal, city, and town construction 
commissions and environmental sanitation bureaus plan, implement, and operate UWM and 
SWM projects.   
 
8.  The urban sector is a priority area for ADB investments in the PRC. ADB has built a 
long-term strategic partnership with MOC over a 10-year period. The partnership is built on the 
implementation of a series of highly relevant and successful TA projects, which focused on 
formulating national policy frameworks and guidelines for the key urban issues facing large and 
medium cities in the PRC. In the late 1990s, ADB provided two TA projects on water tariff 
reforms. The first TA7 examined water tariffs and developed a tariff mechanism based on the 
principles of full cost recovery. A major output of this TA was the preparation of the National 
Guidelines on Water Tariffs (NGWT), which was promulgated by the then State Development 
Planning Commission and MOC in September 1998. The second TA8 focused on developing

institutional capacities to implement the NGWT. Support was provided for preparing the local 
implementing regulations of the NGWT for Chengdu, Fuzhou, and Zhangjiakou. The NGWT are 
now being followed nationwide. In 2000, ADB approved a TA on strengthening urban SWM.9 
Completed in 2003, the TA assisted the Government in developing a national policy framework 
and  plans  for  urban  SWM,  refining  the  National  Guidelines  on  Solid  Waste  Tariffs,  and 
conducted related capacity building. In 2002, ADB provided a TA on Preparing the National 
Guidelines for Urban Wastewater Tariffs and Management Study.10 The TA was completed in 
2003  and  assisted  the  Government  in  refining  the  wastewater  tariff  principles,  developing 
national  guidelines  for  wastewater  tariffs,  and  improving  UWM.  It  established  a  strong 
foundation for the formulation of the national urban wastewater tariff guidelines for large and 
medium cities in the PRC, which is expected to be issued in February 2008. 
 
9.  The Government has made significant progress in improving UWM and SWM. However, 
present tariff reform efforts have focused mainly on large and medium cities. The Government 
still faces many challenges in implementing the national wastewater and solid waste tariff 
reforms  in  small  cities  and  towns  because  of  their  special  circumstances  (e.g.,  lack  of 
economies of scale owing to low waste volumes, low income levels of the populations, and 
weak financial capability of the local governments). There is, therefore, an urgent need to 
develop  and  pilot  test  the  national  policy  framework  and  guidelines  for  UWM  and  SWM, 
focusing on small cities and towns in the PRC. The proposed TA is timely and builds on the 
achievements of the earlier TAs on water, wastewater, and SWM. The major lessons learnt from 
past successful TAs with MOC include (i) the importance of commitment and ownership from 
the Executing Agency (EA), (ii) close interaction and cooperation between various stakeholders, 
(iii) the timing of the TA and proper synchronization between the TA and the Government’s 
priorities and plans, (iv) competent and resourceful consultants who are familiar with the local 
situation, and (v) close involvement and supervision by ADB staff.   
 
10.  The proposed TA supports the Government’s environmental improvement objectives as 
set  out  in  the  11th  FYP.  The  TA  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  strategy  for  the  PRC,  which 
emphasizes protection of the environment, improved wastewater, and SWM, particularly in 
urban areas. Wastewater and SWM projects are a major component of the current ADB lending 
pipeline in the PRC. In particular, the TA will support the growing number of ADB investment 
projects addressing urban environmental improvement needs in small cities and towns in the 
PRC.11   
 
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The  impact  of  the  TA  is  improved  UWM  and  SWM  by  developing  national  policy 
frameworks12 for wastewater and solid waste tariffs, including tariff calculation methodologies,

4 
focusing on small cities and towns. The outcome of the TA is an increased rate of wastewater 
treatment and of sanitary disposal of solid waste for small cities and towns.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will (i) assess the volumes and pollution loadings of UWM and solid waste of 
small cities and towns; (ii) develop a methodology for classification of the small cities and towns 
according to a set of criteria including climatic conditions, technological requirements, financing 
needs,  and  socioeconomic  conditions;  (iii)  formulate  national  tariff  policy  frameworks  on 
wastewater  and  solid  waste  for  each  category  of  small  cities  and  towns,  taking  into 
consideration such factors as appropriate and practical technologies, affordability, financing 
options for construction, O&M, and cost analysis of UWM and SWM facilities in selected case 
study small cities and towns;13 (iv) pilot test the national tariff policy frameworks with selected 
case study small cities and towns; (v) finalize the national tariff policy frameworks on the basis 
of  the  pilot  testing;  (vi)  develop  an  institutional  framework,  capacity  building  plan,  and 
information dissemination program for implementing the national tariff policy frameworks; (vii) 
implement the information dissemination program; and (viii) prepare a comprehensive policy 
note related to UWM and SWM. A fully participatory approach will be adopted to understand the 
needs and expectations of the stakeholders, including local communities, and maximize their 
ownership and buy-in. The Government’s strategy for poverty reduction in the small towns and 
cities will be reviewed, the impact of the tariff policy options on the poor will be assessed, and 
specific measures will be proposed to ensure the poor’s access to wastewater and solid waste 
services.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,300,000 equivalent. The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $1,000,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program. The Government has agreed to provide the balance of the cost, 
equivalent to $300,000, for counterpart staff, office space, furniture, administrative support, and 
logistics. Detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  MOC14 will be the EA for the TA and will coordinate with the relevant central, provincial, 
and municipal government authorities. MOC has already designated a coordinator for the TA, 
and will assign the needed counterpart staff to assist the consultants. MOC will establish a 
project steering committee to guide TA implementation. The project steering committee will be 
chaired by the concerned vice minister for MOC, and will include the director generals of the 
Department of Urban Construction and Department of International Relations, and relevant 
officers of the Ministry of Finance and the National Development Reform Commission. A local 
steering  committee  will  be  established  in  each  selected  case  study  city  to  interact  and 
coordinate with the project steering committee, and to provide guidance to ensure smooth 
implementation of the TA. In addition to staff, MOC will provide a suitably furnished office with 
utilities and telecommunication access; local transport for consultants; and materials, maps, 
data, and related documents required by the TA.  
                                                 
13  The case study small cities and towns will be selected by the EA before the commencement of TA fieldwork. One 
major selection criterion is to consider areas where future ADB projects will be implemented. Through discussions, 
the case study cities will be finalized at TA contract negotiations.   
14  MOC has strong capacity to implement the proposed TA based on their excellent track record in implementing the 
earlier TAs.

5 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over an 18-month period beginning in April 2008 and ending 
in October 2009. The total input of consultants is estimated at 77 person-months, consisting of 
17 person-months of international consultancy and 60 person-months of national consultancy. 
The  consultants  will  have  expertise  in,  among  other  things,  urban  development  planning; 
wastewater management, SWM, wastewater treatment technologies, SWM technologies, urban 
infrastructure financing, tariff reforms, environmental policy analysis and formulation, economic 
analysis, institutional analysis, and participatory approaches. The consultants will be engaged 
through a firm in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time). ADB will select and engage the consultants on the basis of the 
quality (80%) of the proposal and the cost (20%) of the services to be provided (the quality and 
cost-based selection method). ADB’s full technical proposal approach will be used to select and 
engage the consultants. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
TA equipment will be procured by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time),  and  will  be  retained  by  the  EA  upon 
completion of the TA.  
 
16.  The  TA  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  within  1  month  of  the 
commencement of services, (ii) an interim report at the end of the 8th month, (iii) a draft final 
report at the end of the 16th month, and (iv) a final report within 1 month of the receipt of 
comments from the Government and ADB on the draft final report. All of these major reports will 
be translated into Chinese. Tripartite meetings will be held between ADB, the Government, and 
consultants to review the inception, interim, and draft final reports.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Urban Wastewater and Solid Waste 
Management for Small Cities and Towns, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  consultants  will  perform  the  following  tasks  in  close  consultation  with  the 
responsible government departments and agencies at the central, provincial, and local levels to 
ensure full acceptance of the technical assistance (TA) outcome. The proposed TA will consist 
of seven closely related work packages1 to be completed by consultant input of 77 person-
months  (17  person-months  international  and  60  person-months  national).  The  consultant 
experts will include the following: (i) environmental policy and strategy specialist (international 
consultant,  8  person-months,  and  national  consultant,  10  person-months);  (ii)  urban 
environmental  infrastructure  planning  specialist  (2  national  consultants,  2.5  person-months 
each);  (iii)  urban  environmental  infrastructure  financing  specialist  (international  consultant, 
3 person-months, and national consultant, 6 person-months); (iv) urban wastewater specialist 
(international consultant, 3 person-months, and 2 national consultants, 2 person-months each); 
(v)  urban  solid  waste  specialist  (international  consultant,  2  person-months,  and  national 
consultant,  3  person-months);  (vi)  urban  wastewater  and  solid  waste  tariff  specialist 
(international consultant, 1 person-month, 2 national consultants, 4.5 person-months each); (vii) 
natural resource and environmental laws specialist (2 national consultants, 3 person-months 
each); (viii) financial and economic specialist (national consultant, 6 person-months); (ix) public 
policy  analysis  specialist  (national  consultant,  5  person-months);  and  (x)  capacity  building 
specialist (2 national consultants, 4 person-months each).  
 
2.  The  team  leader/national  environmental  policy  and  strategy  specialist  (10  person-
months) will, in addition to technical functions, have overall responsibility for the effective and 
timely  implementation  of  the  TA.  The  team  leader  will  foster  close  coordination  between 
international and national consultants; and coordinate with the Executing Agency (EA), other 
related government agencies, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and other international 
organizations  undertaking  related  work  in  partnership  with  ADB.  The  team  leader  will 
periodically report progress to the EA and ADB, and submit high quality reports to ADB and the 
EA. These work packages are summarized below.  
 
3.  The  deputy  team  leader/international  environmental  policy  and  strategy  specialist 
(8 person-months) will, in addition to technical functions, work closely with the team leader to 
coordinate  with  the  EA,  other  related  government  agencies,  ADB,  and  other  international 
organizations. The deputy team leader will assist the team leader to report progress periodically 
and submit high quality reports to the EA and ADB. The deputy team leader will be responsible 
for ensuring the high quality of the English versions of the inception report, interim report, and 
draft final report.

projects that focused on medium and large cities. 
(iii)  Review  the  technologies  currently  employed  for  urban  wastewater 
management  (UWM)  and  urban  SWM,  and  assess  their  impact  on  the 
environment. 
(iv)  Review the socioeconomic framework, collect basic data on UWM and SWM 
in small cities and towns, analyze the information, determine the impact of the 
present levels of service, and recommend the required service levels for 
various urban conditions (including residential, commercial, institutional, and 
industrial  areas).  Evaluate  the  impact  of  UWM  and  SWM  on  local 
communities (including their health and overall quality of life).  
(v)  Review the development and planning aspects of UWM and SWM in small 
towns and cities, and recommend changes and improvements—taking into 
consideration  land  use  and  zoning,  development  trends,  and  small  city 
development plans.  
(vi)  Review existing service levels for UWM and SWM in small cities and towns, 
the projected increase in service levels, cost recovery mechanisms used, and 
how adequate they are for meeting operation and maintenance expenditures.  
(vii)  In a sample of case study small cities and towns, review the existing sources 
and volume of urban wastewater and solid waste, and its impact on the 
surrounding  urban  environment.  Estimate  the  impact  on  small  city 
environments in general and the level of treatment likely to be required. 
Establish a monitoring program that can be implemented in any small city or 
town to develop a database for future investment projects.   
 
B.  Sector and Issue Analysis 
 
5.  This component includes, but is not limited to, the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review the People’s Republic of China (PRC) sector policies and investment 
priorities for the short, medium, and long term in urbanization and urban 
environmental infrastructure services, for cities and towns in general and for 
small cities and towns in particular. 
(ii)  Analyze the status and future trends of the generation and treatment/disposal 
of wastewater and solid waste for small cities and towns. 
(iii)  Analyze  the  environmental,  socioeconomic,  and  public  health  impacts  of 
inadequate urban environmental infrastructure for small cities and towns. 
(iv)  Develop  criteria  for  classifying  small  cities  and  towns  for  developing 
wastewater and solid waste tariff policies, with due consideration to physical 
and socioeconomic factors. 
(v)  Classify small cities and towns into a number of categories for developing 
wastewater and solid waste tariffs. 
 
C.  Formulation of a National Tariff Policy Framework and Development Program for 
UWM and SWM in Small Cities and Towns 
 
6.  This component includes, but is not limited to, the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review  existing  information  and  studies  on  UWM  and  SWM  in  terms  of 
regulations,  standards,  environmental  assessment,  and  planning 
methodology.

12  Appendix 3 
(ii)  Assess strategic plans of UWM, and SWM, including a statement of the 
planning  principles  and  objectives  and  the  overall  development  targets. 
Review the UWM and SWM strategies of small towns and cities in the context 
of their urban master plans, 5-year plans, and environmental plans. Develop 
planning principles and identify key linkages with other utility services such as 
water and energy management. 
(iii)  Review technological and financing requirements for urban environmental 
infrastructure for different categories of small cities and towns in the PRC. 
Identify  and  evaluate  technologies  and  management  options  (sorting, 
collection,  recycling,  reduction,  reuse,  treatment,  landfills,  energy  from 
wastes, etc).  
(iv)  Review the international and PRC experience and good practices in meeting 
the technological and financing needs for urban environmental infrastructure 
for  the  different  categories  of  small  cities  and  towns.  Prepare  the  best 
practices policy note on UWM and SWM. 
(v)  Formulate  and  evaluate  the  most  practical  technological  options  and 
financing  options,  including  public–private  partnerships,  for  urban 
environmental infrastructure for the different categories of small cities and 
towns, with a focus on the interrelationships of technological, financing, and 
tariff options. 
(vi)  Compile and present a number of good practice cases from the PRC and 
other countries, demonstrating long-term UWM and SWM planning and good 
practices for setting wastewater and solid waste tariffs for small cities and 
towns. Review the experience of other international organizations in UWM 
and SWM in the PRC.  
(vii)  Formulate, evaluate, and recommend policy options for wastewater and solid 
waste tariffs for the different categories of small cities and towns, with due 
consideration to social and poverty considerations. 
(viii)  Analyze affordability and willingness-to-pay for wastewater and solid waste 
services,  the  social  and  poverty  impacts,  and  recommend  mitigation 
measures. 
(ix)  Develop a national policy framework on UWM and SWM for small cities and 
towns, including strategies to decentralize UWM and SWM effectively, with 
more responsibility at the small city and town levels. Prepare a best practice 
policy note on UWM and SWM.  
(x)  Formulate a strategic planning framework suited to conditions in the PRC that 
takes into account UWM and SWM constraints and opportunities, and devise 
a  methodology  to  use  the  framework  effectively  for  development  and 
evaluation of strategic options for UWM and SWM for small cities and towns.  
(xi)  Assess existing private sector participants in UWM and SWM in the PRC, 
and identify the required attributes for a successful partnership with the public 
sector.  Identify  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  and  constraints—both 
domestic  and  foreign—on  private  participation.  Develop  objectives  and 
parameters that will promote private sector participation and investment in the 
sector. Formulate recommendations on legal and institutional arrangements 
that would promote private sector participation in UWM and SWM in small 
cities and towns.

Appendix 3   13 
D.  Pilot Testing and Revision of Tariff Policy Frameworks 
 
7.  This component includes, but is not limited to, the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Develop  criteria  for  selecting  small  cities  and  towns  to  pilot  test  the 
recommended tariff policy options, and select case study pilot cities and 
towns according to the selection criteria. 
(ii)  Develop plans for pilot testing the tariff policy options in the selected small 
cities and towns. 
(iii)  Carry out pilot tests in accordance with the pilot project implementation plans. 
(iv)  Revise the national tariff policy framework for UWM and SWM for small cities 
and towns by incorporating the results of the pilot testing. 
(v)  Explore the potential of adopting the clean development mechanism for SWM 
facilities in the selected case study small cities and towns.  
 
E.  Strengthening of the Institutional and Regulatory Framework 
 
8.  This component includes, but is not limited to, the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review the legal framework of the UWM and SWM program; the pollution 
control legislation; and related regulatory frameworks of central, provincial, 
and  municipal  governments.  Recommend  changes  and  improvements  to 
strengthen the capacity to implement programs and enforce legal provisions 
at the small city and town level.  
(ii)  Review  the  existing  institutional  and  management  arrangements,  and 
recommend ways of strengthening legislation and agencies to provide more 
capability and responsibility at the small city and town level. 
(iii)  Hold  discussions  with  relevant  institutions  at  the  central,  provincial,  and 
municipal levels—including the Ministry of Finance, National Development 
and Reform Commission, MOC, State Environment Protection Administration, 
and other concerned government agencies—to assess current administrative 
arrangements, policies, and strategies for urban wastewater management 
and SWM in small cities and towns. 
(iv)  Present a number of good practice cases from other countries, comprising 
examples  of  effective  institutional  and  financial  support  arrangements  for 
urban  wastewater  and  solid  waste  administration,  operation  and 
maintenance, and private sector participation in UWM and SWM.  
(v)  Conduct  case  studies  in  selected  small  cities  and  towns.  Develop  an 
appropriate methodology for establishing and implementing institutional and 
organizational  reforms  at  the  small  city  and  town  level.  Develop  an 
institutional reform strategy and an action plan to establish fully self-financing 
UWM and SWM companies in the selected case study small cities and towns.    
   
F.  Development of Institutional Arrangements and Capacity Building Plan 
 
9.  This component includes, but is not limited to, the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Prepare an initial working paper containing draft recommendations on the 
national tariff policy framework for UWM and SWM in small cities and towns, 
draft recommendations on institutional reform, tariff objectives and calculation 
methods,  institutional  and  legal  arrangements,  and  development  plans.

14  Appendix 3 
Circulate the working paper to central and local governments, government 
agencies, selected UWM and SWM companies in small cities and towns, 
consumer representatives, and other relevant organizations at the central and 
local levels. Invite and record feedback on the preliminary recommendations. 
Undertake field visits to the selected case study cities to encourage their 
early feedback. 
(ii)  Use the detailed comments and feedback received to refine and strengthen 
the  working  paper,  which  will  then  be  incorporated  in  the  interim  report. 
Distribute the interim report to the relevant agencies, local governments, and 
concerned wastewater management and SWM companies for review and 
further comments.  
(iii)  Conduct workshops to present the interim report to policy makers and price 
bureaus at the central, provincial, municipal, and small city and town level; 
and  to  stakeholders.  Facilitate  the  exchange  of  ideas  and  gather  further 
comments on the proposed recommendations.  
(iv)  Support  the  Government—particularly  MOC,  Ministry  of  Finance,  and 
National Development and Reform Commission—in its efforts to disseminate 
the study’s findings to the State Council and other agencies, commissions, 
and ministries. Conduct workshops and seminars to disseminate the findings 
of  the  TA  to  central,  provincial,  and  local  government  agencies;  price 
bureaus; and UWM and SWM enterprises of the small cities and towns.  
(v)  Analyze the institutional requirements and recommend institutional options for 
implementing the recommended UWM and SWM tariff policies of the small 
cities and towns. 
(vi)  Assess the capacity-building needs. Determine the training needs of local 
government  agencies  and  UWM  and  SWM  enterprises  to  develop  their 
capacity  to  implement  the  proposed  institutional  restructuring,  apply  the 
proposed  methodologies  for  tariff calculation, and  prepare  small  city  and 
towns development plans for UWM and SWM.  
(vii)  Recommend ways of improving the tariff approval process for small cities and 
towns.  This  will  require  better  financial  reporting,  financial  planning,  and 
investment budgeting by the wastewater management and SWM enterprises; 
improved data collection and monitoring, including an improved management 
information system for the UWM and SWM enterprises; and the provision of 
funds and incentives to finance these improvements.  
 
G.  Information Dissemination 
 
(i)  Develop a plan for disseminating the results of the TA, including national 
seminars and workshops. 
(ii)  Carry out the information dissemination program. 
(iii)  Recommend  legal  and  institutional  arrangements  to  promote  public 
participation  in  UWM  and  SWM.  Review  the  impacts  of  any  policy 
recommendations on the poor. Develop a public awareness program of waste 
management,  paying  particular  attention  to  opportunities  created  by 
information technology development.

Appendix 3   15 
H.  Reporting  
 
10.  The  TA  consultants  will  submit  (i)  an  inception  report  within  1  month  of  the 
commencement of services; (ii) an interim report, at the end of the 8th month; (iii) a draft final 
report at the end of the 16th month; and (iv) a final report within 1 month of the receipt of 
comments from the Government and ADB on the draft final report. The consultants will also 
produce  the  following  reports:  (i)  assessment  of  the  status  of  discharge  and  treatment  of 
wastewater generation and disposal of solid waste in small cities and towns; (ii) international 
good practices in wastewater and solid waste tariff systems and in urban infrastructure financing 
for small cities and towns; (iii) tariff calculation methodologies suitable for small cities and towns; 
(iv) draft national wastewater and solid waste tariff policy options for different categories of small 
cities and towns (including calculation methodologies), taking into consideration technological 
requirements,  financing  options,  affordability,  and  institutional  capacity;  (v)  results  of 
implementation  of  the  pilot  projects;  (vi)  an  institutional  strengthening  plan;  and  (vii)  a 
comprehensive best practices policy note on UWM and SWM. All of these major reports will be 
translated into Chinese. Tripartite meetings will be held between ADB, the Government, and 
consultants to review the inception, interim, and draft final reports.
